chapter.title: Deploy Services: Ingestion
chapter.para: The sections that follow cover preparing for, installing, and configuring the data ingestion service as part of the services in &PRODUCTABBR;.

section.title: Ingestion: What You Need to Know Before Deployment
section.para: Ingestion and landing zone share a common filesystem. It's very important to have a shared filesystem in place before launching landing zone and ingestion services. &PRODUCTABBR; was developed against GlusterFS as the shared filesystem solution, and this is also the recommended solution for Production environments.
The GlusterFS is mounted as /ingestion on both the ingestion and landing zone hosts. The ingestion server will create the underlying directory structure once it starts up.
Ingestion should be thought of and is a group of servers to facilitate the import of large datasets.

An "Ingestion Group" consists of a minimum of one Maestro server running Tomcat and ActiveMQ with X number of pit nodes running Tomcat only. The value X amount of pit nodes is the number necessary to ingest the appropriate amount of data for a tenant in a reasonable amount of time. Use these guidelines for deployment:

listitem.para: Each Maestro is at minimum an AWS m2.4xlarge machine running Tomcat and ActiveMQ.
Each pit is at minimum an AWS m2.4xlarge machine running Tomcat only.
Each ingestion cluster will need one Mongo IS database served from a Mongo replica set containing at a minimum 3 servers.
Tomcat must be running as root

section.title: Ingestion: Configuration
section.para: The main configuration file for ingestion is the sli.properties file, which is kept in $TOMCAT_HOME/conf/sli.properties.
Modify the contents to suit your own environment:

section.title: Implementing the CPSI Environment in Amazon's AWS
section.para: The CPSI environment provides an integration between the &COMPANYABBR; Ed-Fi ingestion service and education agencies that use the Schools Interoperability Framework (SIF) protocol for interchange of student data. The CPSI environment is able to provide a SIF endpoint for the education agency and translate the incoming data stream to Ed-Fi suitable for ingestion by &PRODUCTABBR;. The environment includes several Windows Server 2008 hosts to run the CPSI software and provide the SIF and ingestion interfaces. The system software will be setup and configured by CPSI and will run in an automated fashion with little monitoring required. These instructions provide the basic environment suitable for the hosting and setup of the software by CPSI.
To implement the CPSI environment:

step.para: Create a VPC (Virtual Private Cloud) in the AWS which allows for a VPN of at least 8 IP addresses.
In the VPC created above, create a VPN containing at least 8 IP addresses.
Spin up three (3) m1.large instances and give them static IP addresses within the block in the VPN created above.
The three instances should be running Windows 2008 Server R2 for the operating system and should include both IIS and MSSQL.
For the following steps, please assume the following hostnames: CPSI01, CPSI02, CPSI03.
CPSI01 and CPSI03 should be given elastic IP (EIP) addresses so that they can communicate externally:
CPSI01 must communicate with the outside world via ssl/443 and remote desktop protocol (RDP).
CPSI03 must communicate with ingestion only via its and ingestions elastic IPs, via ssl/443.
Create an Internet Gateway for this VPC.
Create a route table containing the VPC's subnet and connect it to the internet gateway created in the previous step.
Three security groups should be created. Security Group 1 will correspond to CPSI01, Security Group 2 will correspond to CPSI02, and Security Group 3 will correspond to CPSI03.
Security Group 1:
Inbound 443/ssl from a list of public IP addresses from which files will be accepted via EIP.
Inbound Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) from a list of public IP addresses for maintenance.
Any port/all protocol TO -> CPSI02, CPSI03.
Outbound any port/all protocol.
Security Group 2:
Inbound any port/all protocol FROM <- CPSI01, CPSI03.
Outbound any port/all protocol TO -> CPSI01, CPSI03.
Security Group 3:
Outbound 443/ssl TO -> ingestion (via EIP).
Inbound any port/all protocol FROM <- CPSI01, CPSI02.
Outbound any port/all protocol TO -> CPSI01, CPSI02.
Add a route from the EIP of CPSI03 TO -> the ELB for the landing zone.

note.para: It is recommended that standard security best practices are observed in this environment. For more information, please see the security benchmarks at the Center for Internet Security for more details.
